item.title: Pilates: A Story of Healing & Reinvention
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: When I think back on my illness, getting sick was the easy part, everything that came after was, well, devastating – thereâ€™s no other...
item.content:encoded:
What:
When I think back on my illness, getting sick was the easy part, everything that came after was, well, devastating – thereâ€™s no other way to put it. It was emotionally heartbreaking & physically debilitating; add those two things together and life-altering is what I was left with.

9-years later, the tears still fall freely when processing all Iâ€™ve been through. Iâ€™m not sure Iâ€™ll ever make sense of it, but I do know there have been some great people along the way whoâ€™ve helped me fight the good fight and one of them is my beloved Pilates teacher, Gretchen Wagoner.

Why:
When I first walked into Breathe Pilates on 79th Street in Miamiâ€™s MIMo district, it was an ordinary day, but my journey to get that moment in my life had been nothing short of extraordinary. 6 years earlier…

A neurologist changed my life forever when he said: â€œYou have Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy.â€ Honestly, it didnâ€™t surprise me. I knew it was coming. Not the diagnosis per se, but some kind of life altering news. For months, Iâ€™d been struggling with horrific pain in my lower back that eventually spread to my hands and feet. Like a bad rash, it crept its way up my arms and legs until I was practically immobile.

If youâ€™re a regular blog reader, you probably already know the story. I contracted a virus that sparked a rare neurological condition in my body called, Guillain-BarrÃ© syndrome. Because it wasnâ€™t diagnosed properly and in a timely manner, I now have the chronic version of it known as CIDP.

GBS is when your bodies immune system attacks its own nerves and the chronic version means I suffer neurological inflammation. On any given day, I can experience extreme muscle fatigue, numbness and pain in my extremities and severe soreness in my lower back. At the beginning of my illness, Immunoglobulin therapy helped tremendously, but as time wore on a less aggressive, more stabilizing approach became standard. Meaning…

IVIG got me out of the woods, but the years that followed, became about managing my chronic pain and trying to find some type of new normal. Thatâ€™s the tricky part, no one teaches you HOW to put your life back together after getting sick or HOW to heal with limitations, but itâ€™s been a very real part of my CIDP journey – one I havenâ€™t shared until now.

I was referred to Breathe Pilates by one of my favorite doctors who had heard the owner of the studio, Gretchen Wagoner, was versed in neurological issues. When he told me I should try one of her classes, I rolled my eyes, mumbled something under my breath and changed the subject. I wasnâ€™t being a bad patient, I was scared.

When I was first diagnosed with GBS, I went to physical therapy religiously, but eventually I was advised to find an exercise that would pick up where my PT left off. So â€” I tried a little bit of everything, but either the exercise was too aggressive or the trainer/instructor treated me like I was training for the Olympics (despite knowing my limitations.)

Sooner or later, I would end up flat on my back, in bed with an excruciating neurological flare-up. Sometimes it took days to recover, sometimes weeks. Thatâ€™s the thing about CIDP, exercise too much youâ€™re in pain, not enough, youâ€™re in pain. Itâ€™s a fine line thatâ€™s almost impossible to balance and the fear of crossing it frightened me. So, I scaled back on my physical activity and as a result, started loosing the strength I had gained in PT. My doctor knew I was struggling and urged me to try Pilates. â€œWhat do you have to lose?â€ He said, matter-of-factly.

By the time I met Gretchen, I was in pretty bad shape, both physically and emotionally. I hunched to protect my spine, I was stiff from pain and inactivity and walked with a limp because of a nagging knee injury. The worst part, though, was the overwhelming sadness inside me. Serious illness does that to a person. It blatantly robs you of your physical prowess, then silently invades your psyche â€” until you feel helpless, alone and sometimes angry. I think Gretchen sensed that about me, though, she never said as much.

We started slowly with one-on-one sessions called Privateâ€™s, because I wasnâ€™t well enough to be in an actual class. Gretchen helped me stretch and more importantly, breathe. She taught me that deep breathing was ultimately a way to connect the mind, body and spirit, which is exactly what I needed, although, I didnâ€™t know it at the time. By the way, I liked Gretchen instantly, but I had my reservations about Pilates. I had been through so much suffering, why would THIS be any different ?

Week after week, session after session, Gretchen earned my trust. She was smart, funny and compassionate. She studied up on my GBS/CIDP and when my physical limitations held me back or scared me, she found different solutions; helping me rediscover myself and my body. I learned to open my chest, articulate my spine and build strength in my core area (which are the ab, pelvis and back muscles.) Eventually, I felt like a different person. I had less chronic pain and more body confidence. My limp disappeared and my posture improved.

If youâ€™ve made it this far in the blog, I want you to know, it hasnâ€™t always been unicorn and rainbows. â€œPilates: A Story of Healing and Reinventionâ€ is and continues to be a lot of hard work and dedication. Like any exercise worth doing, Gretchen says, â€œconsistency is keyâ€ and while Iâ€™ve been committed, sometimes my CIDP has other plans for me. I still have flare-upâ€™s, but the good news is, they happen less often, theyâ€™re less acute and…

When I make it to the other side of a painful few days in bed, nauseous from neuro meds and hazy from pain, Gretchen is always waiting for me â€” with a kind smile, words of encouragement and exercises to help me feel better. That in itself gives me strength.

Pilates hasnâ€™t just helped my body, for the first time in a long time, I have hope again…that Iâ€™m going to be okay and that my new normal, my reinvention if you will, is the person I was always meant to be and while most of my stories have endings, this one doesnâ€™t, because Iâ€™m busy living it and thatâ€™s the good part: just living â€” and that will always be one of my Favorite Things.

Where:
Breathe Pilates Miami
715 NE 79th Street
Miami, Florida 33138

www.breathepilatesmiami.com

â€œChange happens through movement and movement heals.â€â€” Joseph Pilates

This blog runs in tandem with an article in the latest issue of Pilates Style Magazine, featuring my road to recovery and how Gretchen has become my secret weapon in my fight against CIDP. While you have to be a digital member of the magazine to read the article, I promise to share it once it becomes available to everyone.

item.title: Boho City Chic
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Playing dress-up at Boheme Boutiqueâ€™s newest location inside Paradise Plaza in the Miami Design District â€” bringing beautiful bohemian styles to the heart of...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Playing dress-up at Boheme Boutiqueâ€™s newest location inside Paradise Plaza in the Miami Design District â€” bringing beautiful bohemian styles to the heart of the Magic City.

Why:
Iâ€™ve always considered myself bohemian; an independent woman wandering the world doing things on her own terms, but as Iâ€™ve grown older (and happen to be staring a pivotal birthday in the face,) Iâ€™ve realized, perhaps, I never fully understood the true nature of the word â€” until recently. Part of the reason I just assumed I knew what it meant was because of my New Mexico roots: a state filled with artists, actors and free spirited, hippie-dippy-minded people. I thought growing up in that kind of environment gave me an inside track to an unconventional lifestyle and a free pass to express myself without traditional guidelines. And, for the most part, I did.

I spent weekends wandering around Santa Fe in billowy skirts and Birkenstocks, draped in turquoise with fuzzy hair and big dreams. I went to the opera, watched flamenco dancing (Maria Benitez is my favorite,) meandered up Canyon Drive where my mother showcased her oil paintings at Pipe Dreams Gallery and roamed the Georgia Oâ€™Keefe Museum so many times, I knew it by heart. Donâ€™t tell my mom, but I climbed the stairs to the Coyote Cafe bar so often, I knew that by heart, too. The adventures of the desert raised me and because of that I thought I was automatically bequeathed the hippie/bohemian badge of honor.

Grounded by the Southwest sunsets and the purity of a small town, I set out on my own lifeâ€™s journey to find myself, although I was pretty sure I already knew who I was. By the way, I didnâ€™t. Not a clue and that would be the first of many awakenings. Then â€” I did something that went against everything I was raised to be: I chose a high octane, aggressive, multidisciplinary television career or as I like to say, it chose me. My billowy skirts and Birkenstockâ€™s gave way to suits and heels and my carefree attitude turned into sharp concentration with a steadfast purpose.

When times got tough, I would cry and wonder why I traded being a daughter of the desert for big city dreams and a career that seemed almost unattainable. Still, I pressed on and when things got really bad, I went home to New Mexico to regather my strength and recharge my spirit. Each time, though, I felt a little less bohemian and knew that part of me was changing or at least, merging with something else.

As the years passed, I slowly became the journalist I had always dreamed of, but constantly wondered why I had turned my back on the path of least resistance. Wasnâ€™t being a hippie in my beloved Land of Enchantment the person I was meant to be? For old time’s sake, Iâ€™d get out a billowy skirt, my Old Gringo cowboy boots and drape myself in my favorite confetti turquoise necklace my mom gifted me and walk around whatever town I was currently calling home. I convinced myself I was a nomad gypsy, floating around in search of my true destiny. Then…

I moved to Miami and found myself in a place just as special as Santa Fe. The spirituality of the water, the magical surf and sand â€” it was different than the desert, but its pull was just as intoxicating. For the first time in a long time I felt like I was home, even though technically I was thousands of miles away from it. Is it possible to love two places equally? Time would tell.

Along the way, I met Edit Meurrens. A beautiful woman with a radiant smile and kind spirit. She oozes sophisticated confidence. We worked together four years ago on â€œA Bohemian Winter,â€ a blog featuring fashions from her store Boheme Boutique on Key Biscayne. I was attracted to her clothing because they reminded me of home and she did, too. Edit had that hippie vibe without even trying, but it was mixed with city sensibility.

When I heard she was opening another location in the Design District, I was immediately interested and wondered how her boho fashionings would resonate in Miami proper. The new store is gorgeous, snuggled into Paradise Plaza and has the same zen vibe as her flagship on Key Biscayne. The boutique is filled with goodies from Love Shack Fancy, Zimmerman, Spell & The Gypsy Collective, to name a few. Whether youâ€™re shopping for a special occasion, a beach day or vacation, youâ€™ll find the beautifully unique at Boheme Boutique. Iâ€™m a sucker for the accessories, too: basket purses, bejeweled clutches, statement jewelry, fabulous hats… the list goes on.

The best part for me? Realizing the store’s â€œBoho City Chicâ€ personality is the perfect mix of who Iâ€™ve actually become. A desert girl-slash-mermaid-slash-big city career woman. Thereâ€™s no proper emoji for that kind of hybrid. With that being said: age has also made me realize being bohemian isnâ€™t about where you are, geographically speaking, or what youâ€™re wearing, itâ€™s about a sense of freedom on the inside. Independence of thought, kindness in spirit and forgiveness and acceptance of your own humanity. Itâ€™s something Iâ€™m still working on, but at least now I have two beautiful places (New Mexico & South Florida) to be â€œBoho City Chicâ€ and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s one of my #FavoriteThings. Happy Shopping !

item.title: Colors of Cuba
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Celebrating the opening of â€œHouse of Yasâ€ in Sunset Place, a couture fashion house with an authentic Cuban flair created by designer Yas Gonzalez....
item.content:encoded:
What:
Celebrating the opening of â€œHouse of Yasâ€ in Sunset Place, a couture fashion house with an authentic Cuban flair created by designer Yas Gonzalez. #StandOutMiamiStyle

Why:
Artistic, provocative and incredibly unique â€” thatâ€™s how Iâ€™d describe designs by Yas Gonzalez and honestly, thatâ€™s just the tip of the iceberg, but since itâ€™s South Florida, letâ€™s go with the tip of a tropical oasis surrounded by the beauty of deep blue oceans, lush greenery and island architecture. In fashion terms, Yas creates sultry pieces reminiscent of 80â€™s Versace mixed with structured lines of modern day designer, Philip Lim.

I first discovered â€œHouse of Yasâ€ last summer when someone suggested I feature the #HavanaCollection, an ode to Yasâ€™ beloved home country of Cuba. The limited edition line consists of dresses, skirts, shirts and swimsuits decorated with iconic Havana landmarks. Yas took the photos herself and transferred them onto her body-con pieces. She even designed with her childhood memories in mind, like her grandmotherâ€™s decorative tiled floors and viola. Beautiful prints with lively personalities were born, but…

As fashion fate would have it, a collaboration with Yas would have to wait â€” to accommodate her worldly schedule. She was busy traveling to places like New York, Vancouver and Dubai to showcase her work. If thatâ€™s not impressive, how about the people sheâ€™s creatively clothed: Jennifer Lopez, Ricky Martin, Lady Gaga and more recently, #ShireenFavoriteThings.

Yas is also participating in Miami Swim Week (which is in full swing right now.) Itâ€™s where she got her start four years ago, designing an eye-popping bathing suit line right out of fashion school. Its success motivated her to open her atelier, which progressed into her first brick and mortar: â€œHouse of Yasâ€ at Sunset Place in South Miami.

Thatâ€™s when the fashion stars finally aligned and â€œColors of Cubaâ€ came alive when I walked into Yasâ€™ new boutique. Not only are her designs one of a kind, youâ€™ll be the life of the party in one of her pieces. Yas describes them as â€œLa Vida es un carnival,â€ (life is a carnival) and while I agree with that spirit, I also relish in the powerful individuality of what she creates. Iâ€™m not the only one whoâ€™s noticed..

Yas has been featured in British Vogue, GQ and Vanity Fair. While you can shop just about any trend at â€œHouse of Yas,â€ Iâ€™m most attracted to her stunning special occasion dresses. I feel like a million bucks in them and thatâ€™s the point. Sheâ€™s the kind of designer who creates in a way that extinguishes vulnerability and celebrates the female form, in all its gorgeous glory and thatâ€™s why I love wearing â€œColors of Cubaâ€ â€” one of my new #FavoriteThings.

item.title: Summer Fun
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Fashionably frolicking on Miami Beach in the hottest one-piece styles of the summer from â€œBikini Island Swimwear.â€ Think retro suits from the 80â€™s &...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Fashionably frolicking on Miami Beach in the hottest one-piece styles of the summer from â€œBikini Island Swimwear.â€ Think retro suits from the 80â€™s & 90â€™s: high cuts, low backs, a lot of texture and a little leopard print never hurt nobody. #Meow

Why:
When it comes to celebrating a womanâ€™s body, no one does it better than Sports Illustratedâ€™s annual Swimsuit Edition. Not only is the magazine changing the way the world perceives beauty, itâ€™s also changing the way women see themselves. How do I know? Because itâ€™s changed me.

Gone are the days of unattainable beauty and overly airbrushed bodies. Instead, SIâ€™s images are steadily being replaced with voluptuous curves, athletic builds and alluring individuality. In other words, REAL women are finally being celebrated and as a former beauty queen, waif-era model and current on-air television personality, itâ€™s not only a relief, itâ€™s empowering.

For years, alongside most women, Iâ€™ve held myself to unrealistic beauty standards. The constant dieting, working out and overall self-criticism has been exhausting, but now, instead of trying to be something Iâ€™m not, Iâ€™m slowly reprogramming myself to love the skin Iâ€™m in. While itâ€™s good for the self-esteem, itâ€™s definitely a process, especially after decades of being put under the beauty microscope by pageant officials, modeling agents and television consultants â€” who all wanted to transform me into THEIR definition of pretty â€” which honestly, was never the best version of myself. In fact, it was usually the opposite.

Thank God those days are over and I can focus on things like â€œSummer Funâ€ â€” my annual bathing suit blog featuring the latest and greatest in swimwear trends. Usually, I build a high-fashion theme around basic beachwear, but not this year. Instead, as an ode to Sports Illustrated, I wanted to peel back the layers of my body insecurities and keep things more natural while featuring looks from â€œBikini Island Swimwearâ€ in Fort Lauderdale.

The boutique is a rare jewel in this â€œbuy it onlineâ€ day and age. Owner & Professional Fashion Stylist, Marielle Voets Ortiz, believes choosing a bathing suit should be an intimate experience. Touching the material, seeing the textures and ultimately trying it on is the key to finding what truly fits your body and personality. Marielle is also from Europe and used to boutique-style shopping and wanted to bring that type of experience to South Florida women. She combs the globe to find the most chic and sophisticated styles to fill her store with swimsuits, cover-upâ€™s, summer fashions and accessories.

Everything Iâ€™ve worn from her store makes me feel confident and classically on trend, which is no easy task considering my swimsuit standards are incredibly high. Itâ€™s one thing to snap a photo on a blog, itâ€™s another to wear a suit with reckless abandon on a girls’ weekend to Key West or to Miami Beach running, jumping and swimming in the ocean â€” which is exactly what I did in each of these fabulous one-pieces. I felt so comfortable, I even rolled around in the sand a few times.

And while itâ€™s eternally summer in South Florida, trends are still changing with the seasons in the rest of the world. This year, high- cut, low-back one-pieces are all the rage. Think 80â€™s & 90â€™s-style swimsuits worn by some of the original SI models like Christie Brinkley, Kathy Ireland and more recently, Tyra Banks. Pretty beading, crochet overlays and fun prints keep the look modern. When choosing a suit, I think of four things: comfort, style, sophistication and sex appeal. The â€œSummer Funâ€ trend incorporates all of them, mixed with a healthy dose of pizzazz and what South Florida girl doesnâ€™t like a little or a lot of that? During our sweltering, half-naked, wearing-as-little-clothes-as-possible months, remember…

Loving and accepting yourself in any capacity takes work, but itâ€™s worth doing when the end result is #selflove & #selfempowerment and with more realistic images of the female body, thanks to publications like SI, â€œSummer Funâ€ isnâ€™t such a bad place to be and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s one of my #FavoriteThings. Happy summer, fashionistas!

Fort Lauderdale, Florida 33308

item.title: A Cabana Clutch
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Discovering Christinaâ€™s Cabana Clutches, perfect for the South Florida fashionista who needs chic versatility for beach days, brunch plans and dinner dates. #HelloSummer â›±...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Discovering Christinaâ€™s Cabana Clutches, perfect for the South Florida fashionista who needs chic versatility for beach days, brunch plans and dinner dates. #HelloSummer

Why:
There are three key ingredients a South Florida girl needs to survive summer in the tropics: a strong sunscreen, a stylish SPF hat and an easy, breezy clutch thatâ€™ll take you from day to night, no questions asked. The first two Iâ€™ve always had a pretty good handle on; the last one? Not so much â€” until a few weeks ago.

Thatâ€™s when I met Christina McGuire, the creator of â€œChristinaâ€™s Cabana,â€ an on-line boutique specializing in tropically-inspired clutches. The first time I saw one of her pretty purses on Instagram, I was smitten, but it was the story of WHY she created them that inspired me to write â€œA Cabana Clutchâ€…

Christina started her bag business out of sheer fashion frustration and believe me, most of us have been there. Youâ€™re about to wear an amazing dress, youâ€™ve accessorized it with fabulous jewelry, you even have sassy sandals to match, but your handbag? Itâ€™s got more issues than Vogue (I read that once on a coffee cup.) Anyway, you try on every single clutch in your closet, but nothingâ€™s quite right â€” theyâ€™re either too big, too small, the wrong color, the wrong texture or itâ€™s the wrong time of day and the list goes on…

Thatâ€™s when Christina took matters into her own hands and created â€œA Cabana Clutch.â€ Itâ€™s just what she needed, too: a bag streamlined enough to go with any outfit; adding details, like fringe, gave it posh personality. She knew she was onto something: she would go out with her friends and they kept commenting on her coordinated clutches. Each time they urged her to make more, eventually convincing her to pursue purse-making full-time and lucky for us, â€œChristinaâ€™s Cabanaâ€ was born. Crazy enough, that was only six months ago.

After her pet project turned into a bonafide business, Christina expanded, selling her clutches in select retail stores like #BrinyBoutique who provided the gorgeous dresses for the blog. She also started utilizing social media to promote her purses and thatâ€™s where I come in. Isnâ€™t Instagram a beautiful thing? After we connected, we planned out a #FavoriteThings feature.

In person, Christina has a radiant glow about her, but itâ€™s her bubbly personality that I really adore and both attributes are definitely infused into her contemporary, fringe and/or pom-pom creations. Christina also has a deep appreciation for all things tropical; naming her Cabana Clutches â€œThe Golden Tan,â€ â€œThe Oysterâ€™s Pearlâ€ and â€œThe Beach Bar,â€ just to name a few. No two are alike either, because she hand-makes them so theyâ€™re uniquely one-of-a-kind.

Whether your dressing up or down, â€œA Cabana Clutchâ€ will effortlessly connect the dots in your ever-changing wardrobe. Even better, youâ€™ll be able to go from day to night without ever missing a stylish beat and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s one of my Favorite Things.

item.title: Golden Fingers
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Discovering Pharaoun Cocktail Rings â€” perfect for the woman who loves to fancy-up her fingers. Yes, that would be me. After all, Iâ€™m an...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Discovering Pharaoun Cocktail Rings â€” perfect for the woman who loves to fancy-up her fingers. Yes, that would be me. After all, Iâ€™m an unabashed ring girl. Dahhhhhling.

Why:
I donâ€™t know how, when or why it happened, but somewhere between adolescence and womanhood, I became a bonafide #RingGirl. Itâ€™s not like I have swan hands, either. In fact, when I was growing up, my brothers bequeathed me the title â€œFlintstone Fingersâ€ (the famous cartoon characters known for their chubby hands & feet.) I hated the nickname, but instead of trying to distract from my meaty digits, I celebrated them by painting my nails and wearing any kind of sparkly jewels I could get my hands on. Eventually, flashing my fingers turned into a full-blown love affair with rings. Mainly, statement ones.

For me, a ring isnâ€™t just an extension of my personality; it reflects my mood, enhances what Iâ€™m wearing or, simply put, the presence of one on my pretty pointers makes me happy. Glam, whimsical and sophisticated is what Iâ€™m most attracted to and thatâ€™s exactly what a Pharaoun Cocktail Ring is. Designer Sergio AndrÃ©s Mendoza makes sure of that. His motto: â€œI want you to find a ring that symbolizes a version of yourself that you love.â€

When I first read that quote, I was like, “man, he totally gets me” and Iâ€™m sure a lot of other women feel that way, too. Sergio doesnâ€™t like suggesting which of his designs you should wear; he wants you to find it for yourself. Think of it as an emotional treasure hunt where you get in touch with your own feelings and/or inner goddess-ness. When it comes to choosing one of his creations, he told Ocean Drive Magazine: â€œMaybe it reflects a part of you that you donâ€™t see often but want to be reminded of. Maybe it is your greatest strength. Maybe it is the person you want to be.â€

I first learned about Pharaoun Cocktail Rings when we featured Sergio on Deco Drive, where he was quick to point out his gemstone-esque collections are made right here in Miami and if you look closely, the rings (which are perched on 22k gold over silver) are just as beautiful from the back as the front â€” underneath theyâ€™re decorated with intricate carvings and glass stones. Itâ€™s almost as if the ring talks out loud to its admirers, yet at the same time, whispers something special to the woman wearing it.

With collections named â€œSea Urchin,â€ â€œSuperpowerâ€ and â€œI am Beautiful,â€ you canâ€™t help but feel a connection to Sergioâ€™s jewelry. Especially, in this pop culture climate of â€œI am Woman hear me roar.â€ Who doesnâ€™t want to feel empowered by what theyâ€™re wearing? I know I do. In fact, opening up a little black box with a Pharaoun Cocktail Ring snuggled inside can make a girl glow and thatâ€™s why â€œGolden Fingersâ€ is one of my #FavoriteThings.

pharaoun.com

item.title: Wordy Woman
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Celebrating the Slogan Gown trend in a one-of-a-kind dress made by ISA Couture Fabrics â€” while exploring Miamiâ€™s famed Little Havana. Why: Words mean...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Celebrating the Slogan Gown trend in a one-of-a-kind dress made by ISA Couture Fabrics â€” while exploring Miamiâ€™s famed Little Havana.

Why:
Words mean something â€” itâ€™s a phrase that I live by, especially as a journalist. I pour over thousands and thousands of them a week; creating, crafting, writing and rewriting stories. Not just for television and #FavoriteThings, but in life, too. Intimate exchanges, friendly helloâ€™s, meaningful conversations, spirited debates and heated arguments. Words are everything.

As a writer, theyâ€™re my sanctuary, my therapy, my comfort. The gift of self-expression in written form is a skill Iâ€™ve been honing since grade school. Back in the day, I wrote monster stories, alien stories, love stories and eventually human interest stories â€” which led me to journalism and now, blogging.

Words are an expression of our inner-most thoughts, feelings and emotions. They share joy, pain, sadness, empowerment and if you truly fall in love with them, they become art via poems, books, movies and oration. Yes, I am and will always be a â€œWordy Womanâ€…

Thatâ€™s why I canâ€™t resist the latest haute couture fashion trend known as â€œSlogan Gowns.â€ The idea was birthed by Viktor & Rolf at this yearâ€™s Paris Fashion week. Big, beautiful ball gowns floated down the runway, featuring words & phrases like: â€œIâ€™m not shy I just donâ€™t like you,â€ â€œI am my own muse,â€ and â€œNo photos please.â€ The slogan trend isnâ€™t exactly new, especially with the whole â€œsay how you really feelâ€ on a T-shirt craze â€” which has exploded over the past decade.

Not to be outdone by sayings on coffee cups, purses, gym bags, shoes — the list goes on. This day and age, itâ€™s all about expressing yourself and no word or saying is off-limits, especially if you add a hashtag. Iâ€™m partial to the â€œSlogan Gownâ€ trend because of its quirky, unexpected nature. Pulling the look off isnâ€™t easy, but with the help of ISA Couture Fabrics, originality is not a problem…

The boutique isnâ€™t just a South Florida staple, itâ€™s the best couture fabric store in Miami. Not only is it a family-owned business with more than 50 years experience; its owners, Jason & Jackie Castro, are working hard to modernize the way people understand & utilize fabric, hence the DALEâ€™ dress.

They created it to celebrate the â€œSlogan Gownâ€ trend, adding a unique Miami spin. Combining exquisite tulle and organza, they layered the dress with tropical personality. The detachable train gives it just the right amount of sophisticated drama. If youâ€™re thinking “WOW, thatâ€™s a lot of dress,” well, thatâ€™s kind of the point. ISA Couture Fabrics can help any fashionista stand out in a crowd and thatâ€™s no easy task in a city that eats and breathes head-turning fashions.

Whether theyâ€™re customizing a special dress or elevating textiles for local, national and international designers, ISA Couture Fabrics is doing it like no other place in the Magic City. And, instead of just writing about it, this time Iâ€™m wearing it, too and thatâ€™s why â€œWordy Womanâ€ is one of my Favorite Things. DALEâ€™!

item.title: Runway With the Circus
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Highlights from an amazing night judging Design Mix 2019 â€” a runway show featuring art, fashion and design â€” hosted by The International Interior...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Highlights from an amazing night judging Design Mix 2019 â€” a runway show featuring art, fashion and design â€” hosted by The International Interior Designer Association.

Why:
When someone invites you to judge a fashion event called â€œPeculiarium,â€ with a vintage circus theme, it definitely gets your attention. Step right up! Cue the ring master and feast your eyes on one of the coolest, most creative events Iâ€™ve seen in Miami in a long time. Howâ€™s that for an introduction?

Every year, the South Florida International Interior Design Association hosts Design Mix, an amazing runway competition. Itâ€™s a great concept that pairs design companies with textile sponsors; as a team, they collaborate to create a unique, show-stopping garment. The result? An explosion of originality and innovation on the runway.

Judging the event was not only awe-inspiring, it reignited my passion for fashion. Sometimes, Iâ€™m guilty of getting stuck in an artificial Instagram world, where the only mojo available is â€œHow to Keep Upâ€ rather than â€œHow to discover what inspires.â€ At Design Mix…

They use tile, carpet, paint, drapery and other interesting textiles to create the fashion-forward, festive and even freakish — it was a circus theme, after all. The Scottish Rite Masonic Temple, in the Valley of Miami overlooking the river, was the backdrop for the stylish soiree, and it didnâ€™t disappoint. The Egyptian-inspired architecture added a sense of mystique to the already magical â€œPeculiarium,â€ theme.

Before the runway show, there was a cocktail party where circus food like hot dogs, french fries, peanuts and popcorn were on the menu, not to be outdone by a photo booth, adult beverages and carnivalesque performers. The main event opened with clowns, jugglers and the always entertaining Athena Dion, who happens to be one of the most popular drag queens in South Florida. Talk about entertainment!

Once the runway show started, the crowd was electrified, cheering for its favorite model wearing its favorite creation. Each ensemble delivered way more than just a walk down the runway, it was more like a deliberate saunter. Music, background video and choreographed steps were part of each presentation. They pouted/twirled/clawed/grimaced/smiled/danced/lunged, pretty much OWNING their respective themes. It was totally orgasmic, fashionably speaking.

Iâ€™m not gonna lie, judging Design Mix was no easy task. I donâ€™t want to sound clique, but seriously, everyone should have won for pushing the visual envelope. Iâ€™m sure my fellow judges (fashion TV host, Lucia Riano and fashion professor, Mario Braghierri) would agree. There were different winners for different categories, but for overall fabulousness we could only choose one. The winner was … drum roll please …

Edge of Architecture (EOA) was the design firm and TileBar, the sponsor — and yes — tile was one of the outfit’s main themes, not an easy textile to manipulate, mold and eventually master into fashion, but WOW, what an outcome.

Congrats to everyone who worked it like the rent was due or in this case, the mortgage and thank you for inspiring me to take risks and embrace my individuality, which is what fashion is ultimately about. Design Mix 2019 is officially one of my #FavoriteThings. See you next year! Wanna see the winning outfit and other entries? Visit www.ShireenSandoval.com.

item.title: Neon Dreams
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Embracing the bright side of #SpringFashion with a little help from Miamiâ€™s iconic & colorful Little Haiti and trying to figure out why everyone...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Embracing the bright side of #SpringFashion with a little help from Miamiâ€™s iconic & colorful Little Haiti and trying to figure out why everyone is acting a little crazy, including myself. Thanks #MercuryRetrograde.

Why:
Iâ€™m not gonna lie, I wanted to mail this blog in. Put on a cute neon outfit, take a few snaps, write a couple of paragraphs and be done with it, but I canâ€™t because I have all these feelings and emotions gnawing at me and Iâ€™m not sure where to put them and how to deal with them, so writing them down seemed apropos. And, letâ€™s face it, itâ€™s cheaper than therapy.

About four weeks ago, for whatever reason, my phone started blowing up like Mount Vesuvius; favor, after favor, came pouring in. Shireen, can you do a story? Shireen, can you do a blog? Shireen, can you make an appearance? Shireen, can you wear my clothes? Can I borrow something from your closet? Can I stay at your house? Can you meet for lunch? How about dinner? Can you ask James to hook me up with FREE photos? The requests were endless & relentless.

INHALE. EXHALE. Turn phone over as if itâ€™s a piranha about to devour my hand which, coincidentally, did happen a week later – not by a predatory fresh water fish; by a dog leash that accidentally got wrapped around my right hand while walking my beloved Rigby. It snapped back so severely, I fell to my knees and wept. I was so disoriented from the pain, I crawled onto someoneâ€™s lawn and passed out. The doctor fixed me up, ordered me to rest and see a hand specialist ASAP. I didnâ€™t.

The next week, armed with inflammation-reducing pills, ice and tenacity, I muscled my way through my busy life. Ding, ding, ding, ding; my phone wouldnâ€™t stop. Shireen, can I borrow money? Shireen, can you pass my resume to your boss? Shireen, can you get me a job at Channel 7? Shireen, can you feature my hair salon on Deco Drive? Shireen, can you help with my charity? Shireen, can you tell me a good TV agent? Shireen, why arenâ€™t you answering my IG messages? SHIREEN, are you there?

When I mentioned the onslaught of requests/demands/favors to my best friend, Jackie, we talked it out. We came to the conclusion that, more than likely, it was about my boundary issues. I had always had a hard time saying NO and turning a blind eye to people who, for whatever reason, had nabbed my phone number over the years (for stories, blogs or events) and used it with absolutely no discretion. Ahhh…so, thatâ€™s what this was about: taking care of myself. The universe was allowing me to practice and if I didnâ€™t listen, Iâ€™d have to learn the lesson over and over again. Noted.

INHALE EXHALE. Bury phone in stylish purse. Go to CVS. Buy hand brace. Rip package open in car. Fumble with Velcro. Wrap contraption around hand. Lay head on steering wheel. Cry. Go to work. Type with left hand. Carefully drive home. Lay in bed awake. The pain canâ€™t last forever, can it?

By the weekend, my hand started to swell and stiffen and my daily tasks became impossible. I could no longer brush my teeth, put my hair in a pony tail or do Pilates comfortably. I backed off social media, stopped texting as much and promised myself to call the hand doctor first thing Monday morning. Still, life went on. I attended a beautiful wedding, a chic birthday brunch and tried practicing those all-important boundaries…

Message after message, text after text, I replied NO (in one form or another.) If I valued the person and/or organization, I asked politely if they could please STOP pitching stories to my personal phone and/or private social media platforms. More importantly, I called the hand doctor. Nothing. No answer. No returned call. I called another one. Nothing. No answer. No returned call. I fumbled through the next few days in a haze of pain.

Like a broken record, I cried to Jackie about the ongoing barrage of messages and the excruciating pain in my hand. â€œMaybe this isnâ€™t a boundary thing,â€ she said frankly, â€œMaybe itâ€™s because Mercury is in Retrograde.â€ I grew quiet. I didnâ€™t know a lot about astrology, but I did believe in the universe and all of its beautiful mysteries. Mercury. Retrograde. Noted. Will look it up when not in pain. Jackie added: â€œGO TO THE DOCTOR.â€

(If this were a movie, this would be the part where I turn and talk right into the camera: â€œIâ€™m not an idiot. I fully know I should have gone to the doctor earlier. In fact, I should be there right now, but something so medically earth-shattering and tragic happened to me years ago, going to the doctor is a stark reminder of some of the darkest days of my life. Despite therapy and a decent recovery, I suffer chronic pain, CIDP relapses and seem to be prone to injury. So, as you can imagine, denial has turned into a powerful friend. On that note, things are about to get real.”)

INHALE. EXHALE. Walk into television make-up room. Clutch hand. Nauseous. Dizzy. Collapse into chair. Co-worker calls hand doctor. Exam. X-ray. Prognosis. Needle. Pain. Swollen man-hand like Seinfeld episode. Then, like magic, everything stood still. Someone hit the pause button. I couldnâ€™t pick-up the phone, couldnâ€™t blog, couldnâ€™t email, couldnâ€™t be on TV. The universe wanted me to STOP and this time, I listened. Healing is never easy; it takes patience and a willingness to admit your own limitations and frankly, I should be a professional at it by now, but we all have our issues. So, there I was, alone with my fat hand and my mile-a-minute thoughts. I went home, drifted off to sleep and dreamed of #MercuryRetrograde…

An optical illusion that a planet is moving backward, but somehow, it is not: representing communication issues, psychic clutter, frazzled behavior, intensity and if youâ€™re a Leo, like myself, it can pose the question: â€œAm I getting exactly what I want outta life?â€ And, perhaps, most pertinent, Mercury Retrograde can also mean coincidences are extra-ordinary. Demanding favors, aggressive social media messages, hundreds of emails and a hand injury forcing me to IGNORE all of the above. A serendipitous twist of fate? I think not.

They say we dream in black and white, but itâ€™s not true, because just before I woke up from my post-hand procedure nap, I floated through a cocoon of neon colors, mainly, pink and yellow. The vibrancy of the moment stayed with me and is the inspiration for this blog. Google says, â€œNeon Dreamsâ€ represent a person whoâ€™s seeking a solution or a change, in order to find relief. Coincidence? I think not.

My hand is finally healing and for the most part, the crazy favors/messages/demands have stopped. Intensity doesnâ€™t have to be a bad thing, I guess, but how you handle or interpret it can make all the difference. Life is all about pacing: realizing whatâ€™s important and giving those things your unbridled attention. The rest is just noise. A LOT of noise. As I type the last words of this entry, Mercury has officially creeped its way out of retrograde and it seems all is right in the universe again and thatâ€™s why, â€œNeon Dreamsâ€ is one of my Favorite Things.

www.HotMiamiStyles.com

â€œI dream of you in colors that donâ€™t exist.â€ â€” anonymous

item.title: Jumping into Spring
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Celebrating the ease of spring in a Julian Chang one-piece; because chic and effortless jumpers are the perfect way to usher in the beginning...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Celebrating the ease of spring in a Julian Chang one-piece; because chic and effortless jumpers are the perfect way to usher in the beginning of a new season.

Why:
Iâ€™ll never forget the first time I wandered into Julian Changâ€™s boutique on Miamiâ€™s Upper East Side â€” I was mesmerized. His designs were bold, beautiful and original. In fact, Iâ€™d never seen anything like them. I remember it clearly: I was a budding entertainment journalist with little fashion sense and even less money, but for whatever reason, I knew l was seeing something special, so I promised myself a quick return when I had more time and, of course, more moolah..

Believe it or not, THAT moment was over a decade ago. I know, I know, not exactly the quick return I promised myself, but thereâ€™s more to the story than just passing time; which, by the way, has been pretty good to me. Despite a great career and even a few raises over the years, Julian Chang remained one of my elusive fashion unicorns â€” until a few weeks ago…

Thatâ€™s when my Deco Drive Co-Host, Lynn Martinez, casually informed me one of my clothing sponsors wanted to dress HER, not ME. â€œAt least for the time being,â€ she said pleasantly. â€œThe time being?!!! Whatâ€™s that supposed to mean?â€ I asked, flabbergasted. The news really upset me; making matters worse, she delivered the â€œfashion bombshellâ€œ right before our LIVE broadcast.

(If the owner of the boutique wasnâ€™t happy with me or wanted to move in a different direction, why didnâ€™t she tell ME? #Embarrassing and to think Iâ€™d been so loyal, posting social media pictures in her clothing, highlighting the store on my beloved blog AND wearing outfit after outfit of her brand on Deco. Our relationship wasnâ€™t just a passing phase, either; I had been working with the boutique for almost two years. #LiveAndLearn…)

Lynn knew it wasnâ€™t cool either and all but said so. Whatâ€™s more, she knew it was a breach of one of our hard, steadfast rules: NEVER EVER take someone elseâ€™s clothing sponsor. In her defense, SHE wasnâ€™t actually taking anything; THEY were flat-out offering. Lynn was just being transparent about it which I appreciated and when she saw how visibly upset it made me, she insisted she wouldnâ€™t go through with it, especially after I quipped: â€œWhat if I did that to you? You know, just for the time being?â€

I knew at that point, though, no matter what I said or how Lynn reacted, there was NO going back. I wasnâ€™t using the boutique anymore, if only out of principle and I definitely wasnâ€™t going to let television clothing come between Lynn and I. Weâ€™re besties, sisters and sometimes sisters donâ€™t see eye-to-eye, but at the end of the day, weâ€™re family and we love each other and thereâ€™s no midi dress or cute skinny jean trend that could possibly be more stylish than a woman supporting another woman. I relinquished with…

â€œYou have my blessing,â€ but what fell out of my mouth next surprised even me: â€œThey can dress you if I can feature Julian Chang on Favorite Things.â€ Julian had been providing Lynn with wardrobe to wear on Deco for years and because of our hard, steadfast rule of NEVER EVER taking someone elseâ€™s clothing sponsor, I kept my distance and believe me, it wasnâ€™t easy; especially as heâ€™s considered one of the most gifted fashion designers in the Magic City. Alas, my #ElusiveFashionUnicorn.

Without hesitation, though, Lynn generously agreed and DMâ€™d Julian immediately. The Peruvian-born designer, whoâ€™s now a worldwide fashion go-to, was more than happy to help. And, just like that, I was â€œJumping into Springâ€ at Julianâ€™s boutique; modeling three of his easy-peasy, one-piece creations.

If you like sumptuous materials, vibrant colors and generous figure-hugging cuts, you definitely need one of Julianâ€™s jumpers for your spring/summer wardrobe. If youâ€™re more of a dress girl or love a great pair of palazzo pants, his new collection is a must-see: itâ€™s fun, fabulous and functional, especially when it comes to our South Florida weather.

For me, â€œJumping into Springâ€ is so much more than a fashion blog, itâ€™s been a lesson in life. Sometimes, you have to let go of what you think is comfortable to actually find the perfect fit; one youâ€™ve always known existed, but for whatever reason, werenâ€™t brave enough to try on or, in this case, ask for. By the way…

When I confronted the aforementioned boutique owner about her decision to dress Lynn and not me, she responded: â€œDonâ€™t take it personal, I wanted more exposure.â€ Well, unfortunately, I did take it personal, mainly because of the way it was handled. Maybe Iâ€™m wrong, but professionally speaking, I think giving me a heads-up would have been the right thing to do. Honestly, Iâ€™m still trying to wrap my head around it. Iâ€™m human and sometimes, things hurt.

But then again, you have people like Lynn and Julian who restore your hope in mankind. Pushing you forward with fashionable acts of love and kindness. The universe truly is inspiring, especially if youâ€™re open to growing, changing and evolving, after all, thatâ€™s what new beginnings are all about and thatâ€™s why â€œJumping into Springâ€ is one of my Favorite Things.

Where:

7246 Biscayne Blvd.
Miami, Florida 33138

the courage to
turn into spring
who says I canâ€™t

item.title: Timeless Beauty
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Discovering the exquisite and one-of-a-kind time pieces by jewelry designer, Sevan BiÃ§akÃ§i. Theyâ€™re totally, #DropDeadGorgeous and then some ğŸ’« Why: I donâ€™t wear a...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Discovering the exquisite and one-of-a-kind time pieces by jewelry designer, Sevan BiÃ§akÃ§i. Theyâ€™re totally, #DropDeadGorgeous and then some

Why:
I donâ€™t wear a watch. I know, I know, so WHY am I doing a blog about one? Because â€œTimeless Beautyâ€ with Sevan BiÃ§akÃ§i has simply bewitched me, thatâ€™s why. Let me explain…

As a television journalist, I live and die by the clock. I have multiple daily deadlines; meaning Iâ€™m constantly trying to outsmart, outdo and/or outrun father time. So, on my precious days off, reminding myself how little or how much time I have to enjoy myself with a *watch* isnâ€™t exactly relaxing (no matter how cool the technology is.)

When Iâ€™m not at the Deco Drive studios, I try my best to live in the moment and if I do have Pilates, a blog shoot, a hair appointment or a dinner date, I look at my phone and leave my wrists responsibility-free. Itâ€™s the only way I can remain sane in our â€œtime-driven, phone addicted, social media obsessed society.â€

But â€” for whatever reason â€” when Sevan BiÃ§akÃ§iâ€™s email slid into in my inbox a few weeks ago announcing the designer’s foray into timepieces, it peaked my curiosity. So, I clicked & scrolled down to the pictures. WOW! It was awe-inspiring, to say the least. My mind was #shooketh, fashionably speaking, and I knew, right then and there, I had to change my mind about wearing a watch. Whatâ€™s more, I knew I had to feature one of his fabulous time pieces on #FavoriteThings.

Sevan, whoâ€™s no stranger to Hollywoodâ€™s elite (they love wearing his ornate one-of-a kind rings,) has officially upped the ante with the debut of his new watch collection; which he describes as â€œslow luxury.â€ Meaning, his elaborate timepieces are meant to evoke a feeling, not tell you when to run your next errand. Even the designer himself admits telling time on one of his watches isnâ€™t necessarily the goal; itâ€™s about hiding the time, slowing things down and enjoying life and perhaps, its finer things â€” like, say, one of his creations.

One glance at his 85-piece collection, which was recently showcased at Watches & Wonders Miami, and youâ€™ll understand exactly what the Istanbul artist is talking about. His timepieces are pure decadence; taking years to cultivate and create. Not only that, they possess qualities of the mystical and magical, which Sevanâ€™s jewelry is known for. FYI, pictures donâ€™t even do his detailed and impeccable fashionings justice.

In â€œTimeless Beauty,â€ Iâ€™m wearing the â€œNaiadsâ€ â€” which in Greek mythology is a female spirit who presides over bodies of fresh water like fountains, springs, brooks and streams. The gorgeous timepiece is flanked with dragonflies (my spirit nymph) made of 24-karat gold, sterling silver and features over 40 carats of diamonds with sapphire crystals. My favorite part of the watch is the reverse engraved dragonfly on its crystal face, not to mention its graceful carved gemstone dial. #YouFeelMeNow?

Of all the places in the world Sevan could set up shop, he chose Miami and our inspiring Design District for his second boutique. An electrifying thought when you discover his only other store is in his native Turkey. When it comes to â€œTimeless Beauty,â€ the beyond-talented designer is making Miami all the more magical and heâ€™s officially turned me into a bonafide watch-wearer and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s one of my #FavoriteThings.

item.title: Prints & Patterns
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Fashionistas never fear: wearing Spring’s hottest #PrintsAndPatterns doesnâ€™t have to be weird â€” thanks to MVM Miami, one of my favorite boutiques in The...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Fashionistas never fear: wearing Spring’s hottest #PrintsAndPatterns doesnâ€™t have to be weird â€” thanks to MVM Miami, one of my favorite boutiques in The Magic City.

Why:
When Duchess Meghan Markle first burst onto the international fashion scene, I was less than overwhelmed. In fact, I found some of her outfits bland — even boring — and I didnâ€™t care HOW much they cost or WHO the couture designer was â€” I just wasnâ€™t feeling it; but thatâ€™s the thing about love, you forgive easily. Meghan loved Prince Harry and Prince Harry loved Meghan and I was so rooting for their â€˜happily ever after,â€™ I mean, who wasnâ€™t? So, when she stepped out looking like a monochromatic old maid, I looked the other way.

Then â€” somewhere between her royal wedding, numerous public engagements, that never-ending Australian tour and her pregnancy, something in my fashion perception shifted. I realized Meghanâ€™s outfits werenâ€™t stodgy at all, they were streamlined, sophisticated and classy. It wasnâ€™t just the #MarkleSparkle either, although, I do love her smile, it was this innate sense of style she seemed to possess. Maybe it was her stylist/BFF, the now-famed Jessica Mulroney. Maybe it was my need to live more simply (hence, The Blouse Report blog) or maybe I was just exploring new style possibilities. Whatever it was, I started falling for the fashionings of The Duchess of Sussex.

After discovering my new-found taste, I purged my closet, lessening my ‘boho beach-y meets Santa Fe hippy chic’ look and invested in more straightforward dresses and suits; trying to tame my sometimes over-the-top #DecoDrive television fashion persona. Iâ€™m not gonna lie, it was hard and some pieces were impossible to part with, so I settled for a happy medium and wondered if anyone actually noticed. They didnâ€™t …

And so, life goes on and so does the blog and so did my semi-conservative dressing, until low and behold #SS19 whipped my wardrobe overhaul into a complete trend tizzy. Let me back up…Iâ€™ve been wanting to do a feature on MVM Miami for awhile. Itâ€™s not only one of the best boutiques in The Magic City itâ€™s one of my secret weapons when staying fashion-forward on Deco.

When I booked the blog with owner, Melissa Mosheim, she sent some outfit suggestions featuring â€œPrints & Patternsâ€ and I was sold. When doing a little more research on #SS19, it was obvious that monochromatic and color blocking was a thing of winters past. It was all about florals, animal prints, stripes, plaids, paisley, butterflies, snake skin, polka dots, pop art motifs and more. You can even mix your â€œPrints & Patterns,â€ think *more is more* on crack and thatâ€™s where the aforementioned trend tizzy comes in.

With my mind set on the distinctive duchess, I almost forgot about my OWN quirky style and how I love expressing my own lifeâ€™s journey through what Iâ€™m wearing. I grew up in the desert, traveled the world as a journalist and live in one of the most vibrant cities in the world; if that doesnâ€™t scream â€œPrints & Patternsâ€
I donâ€™t know what does. Now, Iâ€™m just trying to find an eclectic balance and thatâ€™s why MVM Miami boutique works for someone like me. Itâ€™s worldly, avant-garde, yet romantic and Miami-esque. Itâ€™s a store with a pulse for whatâ€™s happening on the runway and in real life.

Spring is the the perfect time for new beginnings, reinvention or adding â€œPrints & Patternsâ€ back into your wardrobe and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s one of my Favorite Things. PS. Just in the nick of time, Meghan wore a flower-y print dress last week to one of her royal engagements. #TwinningIsWinning

item.title: In The Bag
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Celebrating SS19 by Ximena Kavalekas & checking out her new retail space at the Faena Bazaar on Miami Beach. Hello, lovahâ€¦. ğŸ‘› Why: You...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Celebrating SS19 by Ximena Kavalekas & checking out her new retail space at the Faena Bazaar on Miami Beach. Hello, lovahâ€¦.

Why:
You know the song, â€œGirl On Fire,â€ by Alicia Keys? Well, she must have written the catchy tune for handbag designer, Ximena Kavalekas. Thereâ€™s literally #NoStopping the woman. In fact, her success has been so meteoric, I actually have trouble keeping up with it and thatâ€™s what I do for a living.

The first time I met Ximena back in 2016, her luxury handbag line was launching from a small room inside â€œThe Fashion Workspace of Miami,â€ but my-oh-my, have things changed. Not only has she set up shop inside the world class Faena Bazaar, her handmade python accessories are being worn by the Whoâ€™s Who of Hollywood: Priyanka Chopra, Sofia Vergara, Sofia Carson and even fashion queen, Margherita Missoni. Speaking ofâ€¦

Margherita, who happens to be a huge fan of Ximena’s, recently collaborated with her on a limited-edition handbag series. Going with Ximenaâ€™s signature #BoxBag style, the two women created â€œa simple yet sophisticatedâ€ petite suitcase-like design. I especially adore the colors of the #Capri, not to mention its decorative zigzag star stitching which is a combination of the duoâ€™s initials: MM + XK â€” what a chic and fashionably witty idea. Its whimsical laser cut daisies are the perfect finishing touch #BeautifulBag.

If all that werenâ€™t enough, Ximenaâ€™s purses are breezing their way through Bergdorf Goodman, Bloomingdales, NET-A-PORTER, Saint Germain, Moda Operandi, the retail elite list goes on and donâ€™t even get me started on the editorials: Vogue Mexico, Vogue Brazil, Vogue India, Elle, People, US Weekly, DUJOUR, InStyle, Miami Magazine, Brickell Magazine, just to name a few. This is where the DJ pipes in: â€œThis girl is on fireâ€¦â€

Bloggers love Ximena, too. Iâ€™d include myself in that group, but television is my full-time job and blogging is what I do to express my love of fashion with, of course, Channel 7 as my partner in crime. Speaking of, Ximena is always supportive of local media, especially #DecoDrive and understands the importance of connecting on that kind of level. In fact, her second bag collaboration is with Miami Fashion Stylist extraordinaire, Elysze Held, who runs â€œThe Magic Cityâ€ when it comes to what and whom you should be wearing.

In full disclosure, Elysze styles for Deco Drive and her fab personality coupled with her elegant fashion sense is sure to produce the IT bag of the season. I canâ€™t wait to see what Ximena & Elysze come up with. I better start saving my money now. Hmmm… what about a Go Fund Me fashion account ? In all seriousness…

Iâ€™m so happy for the success of the #XimenaKavalekas brand. Not only is it deserving, Ximena has stayed firmly planted in South Florida; making the Miami fashion scene better, brighter and exponentially more beautiful..you might say, Ximena has it all â€œIn The Bagâ€ and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s one of my #FavoriteThings.

item.title: Pretty at the Pegasus
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Ooh-ing & ahh-ing over race day runway fashions by Neiman Marcus at Bal Harbour Shops â€” celebrating the Pegasus World Cup 2019 Championship Invitational...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Ooh-ing & ahh-ing over race day runway fashions by Neiman Marcus at Bal Harbour Shops â€” celebrating the Pegasus World Cup 2019 Championship Invitational Series. #GiddyUp

Why:
When I first got the invite to attend the â€œOff to the Racesâ€ fashion show celebrating the Pegasus World Cup, I wasnâ€™t sure what to expect. Iâ€™ve been to the Kentucky Derby before and I can assure you: style-wise, itâ€™s world’s away from anything going on in South Florida.

Iâ€™m not a big fan of ginormous hats, bold flowery prints and aggressive pearl accessories â€” especially when worn together â€” and thatâ€™s definitely something youâ€™ll see at â€œRunning of the Rosesâ€ (one of the Derbyâ€™s nicknames.) Lucky for me, and Miami fashionistas, Pegasus is an entirely different style event.

The race itself is incredibly prestigious because of its 16 million-dollar purse, the largest in North American thoroughbred racing, but itâ€™s also the glamorous crowd attending that makes it so popular and appealing. In fact, every year Deco Drive does a story on the rich, famous & fashionable who show up to show off what theyâ€™re wearing.

Taking a cue from The Whoâ€™s Who of the premier event, Neiman Marcus Bal Harbour & Pegasus World Cup teamed up for the first time last week for an elegant runway show featuring race day fashions with a Miami flair. After all, weâ€™re not in Kansas anymore — or would that be Kentucky?

Beautiful dresses, form-fitting suits and fancy fascinators stole the spotlight. Iâ€™ve included pictures of some of my Favorite Things from the show highlighting this spring’s biggest trends…because with outfits like these, frankly, weâ€™re all â€œPretty at the Pegasusâ€ and thatâ€™s what I call #winning.

item.title: The Blouse Report
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Who doesnâ€™t love a great blouse? Itâ€™s the perfect way to perk up your winter wardrobe. Why: A lot has happened since my last...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Who doesnâ€™t love a great blouse? Itâ€™s the perfect way to perk up your winter wardrobe.

Why:
A lot has happened since my last post: I went on a mini-vacation with three of my best friends, worked like an animal through the holidays, made a new yearâ€™s resolution to buy more blouses AND took a long break from the blog.

I needed it. Now, Iâ€™m refreshed and ready to tackle 2019 with style and hopefully, substance. First up on my fashionable list for the new year: â€œThe Blouse Reportâ€ …and while Iâ€™d love to say the garment is making a cool comeback, the truth is I donâ€™t think itâ€™s ever really gone out of style.

The blouse trend of the moment is something the French call â€œThe Pussy Bow Blouseâ€…which features a big sumptuous bow at the top of its button line. It was bequeathed the cheeky title back in the 19th century by aristocrats who insisted the fashion statement reminded them of fancy cat collars.

The blouse really bloomed in popularity during the Gibson Girl era, when women expressed themselves through cascading waterfall curls and high-collar, button-up shirts with fancy neck tie accessories; mainly, the pussy bow. By the 1960â€™s, Coco Chanel & other haute couture designers made the blouse modern while keeping its feminine frivolity intact.

Now, in a day and age where anything goes fashion-wise, the blouse has a lot of different personalities: gypsy, Boho, fancy, casual and professional. Staying on trend means adding a blouse with a bow, no matter the size of its loops. I love mixing romance with structure, so I usually pair mine with my favorite Filomena Fernandez work pants. If you prefer a more masculine take on the trend, wear a necktie instead.

My resolution for 2019 is about living life simply which isnâ€™t always possible in my high octane career, but â€œThe Blouse Reportâ€ adds an easy sophistication to my sometimes complicated life & wardrobe, thatâ€™s why itâ€™s one of my Favorite Things.

item.title: The Winterfest Black Tie Ball
item.dc:creator: Steven Cejas
item.description: What: A festive night of dinner & dancing at the Seminole Hard Rock Winterfest Black Tie Ball presented by Ford, in association with Republic National...
item.content:encoded:
What:
A festive night of dinner & dancing at the Seminole Hard Rock Winterfest Black Tie Ball presented by Ford, in association with Republic National Distributing Co. #HappyHolidays & hereâ€™s to my #FavoritePartyOfTheYear

Why:
Before the Winterfest Boat Parade sets sail, the Black Tie Ball officially kicks off the holiday season in South Florida. While Iâ€™ve had the great privilege of hosting the event for almost a decade, Iâ€™ve never done a blog on it. Itâ€™s always such a stylish, awe-inspiring soirÃ©e, so, why not?

The musical, â€œAnastasia,â€ by Broadway Across America, was this year’s theme, transporting party goers from the decadence of old Russia to the romantic streets of Paris. If youâ€™re not familiar with the production, good news â€” the musical is making its way to the Broward Center for the Performing Arts in the spring and itâ€™s definitely a must-see.

This yearâ€™s Ball happened to be extra special because my Deco Drive TV wife, Lynn Martinez, joined me for the FIRST time at the gala and man, did we cut a rug. My dogs are still barking. LOL. When we were dancing, I think we scared everyone within a half mile radius, except for one of our producers, Danny Cohen, who was busy showing off his Pulp Fiction moves. We did our best Uma & John impression from the famous dance scene in the movie.

Vivian Gonzalez, one of our rock star meteorologists at Channel 7, was also on hand. The Viv-ster, as I loving call her, had her â€œBust A Moveâ€ shoes on, too. Both Viv-ster and myself were lucky enough to wear gowns by Zola Keller who, by the way, has an amazing store on Las Olas in Fort Lauderdale. If you need a WOW kind-of dress for any occasion, she should be your go-to, sheâ€™s definitely one of mine.

The Black Tie Ball is, of course, the precursor to the Winterfest Boat Parade, which is celebrating its 47th anniversary this Saturday with the theme: â€œBest of the 80â€™sâ€. I canâ€™t wait to see all the shoulder pads, blue eye shadow and teased hair. Iâ€™ll have to pull out my vintage â€œLike A Virginâ€ Madonna-esque lace gloves. Speaking of the 80â€™s, pop icon Huey Lewis is this years Grand Marshall.

I’m looking forward to seeing him cruising down the New River in downtown Fort Lauderdale singing â€œI Want A New Drug …one that wonâ€™t make me sick” or “happy to be ..Stuck With You.â€Â Â If you havenâ€™t see the â€œGreatest Show on H20â€, I highly recommend it. Itâ€™s Floridaâ€™s version of the Macyâ€™s Day Parade, except our floats really do float and our weather is waaaay better than NYC this time of year and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s one of my Favorite Things. Happy Winterfest everyone!

item.title: Party Pizzazz
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Gearing up for the glitz and glamour of the holiday season with dresses & accessories by Dominque Boutique in Coral Gables. Oh, and did...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Gearing up for the glitz and glamour of the holiday season with dresses & accessories by Dominque Boutique in Coral Gables. Oh, and did I mention Iâ€™m headed to The Keys for the ultimate girls trip?

Why:
By the time you read this, Iâ€™ll be barreling toward Key West with three of my closest friends. Each are besties from different decades of my life and strangely, theyâ€™ve never met one another. God help us! Lol. Itâ€™s going to be â€œThelma & Louiseâ€ on crack.

Who needs to drive off the edge of the Grand Canyon, though, when you have places like Aqua Night Club? Famous for its cabaret Drag shows! Or Louieâ€™s Backyard? Where a decadent martini can only be upstaged by a spectacular Key West sunset. Iâ€™ve even seen â€œpeopleâ€ skinny dip right by Louieâ€™s popular pier-inspired porch.

If Iâ€™m arrested, it probably wasnâ€™t my fault (wink, wink.) Seriously, though, itâ€™s a trip Iâ€™ve been looking forward to for a really long time. Itâ€™s such a rarity, Iâ€™ve bequeathed it the title: â€œRock Star Weekend.â€ Eating, drinking, shopping, laughing, reminiscing. Iâ€™ll be in full beast mode and my best friends will be right there with me. So, what does any of this have to do with holiday fashion? Everything, nothing and something.

Iâ€™ve actually been struggling with a meaningful topic to share during â€œthe Most Wonderful Time of the Year,â€ but then it dawned on me, the very essence of my girlie getaway is the perfect way to explain how many of us long to feel during Hanukkah, Christmas & on New Years Eve, and Iâ€™m not talking about bloated, tipsy and anxiety ridden because youâ€™ve spent too much on your credit card. Iâ€™m not judging #BeenThereDoneThat

Iâ€™m talking about human connection, which in turn, can make a person feel special. Iâ€™ve been to The Florida Keys more times than I can possibly count, lucky me, but each trip is marked with the memories of whom I shared it with and how it made me feel at the time. Whether it was friendship, love, intimacy or heartbreak, theyâ€™re all an indelible part of who I am now.

The same holds true for â€œParty Pizzazzâ€. It may sound corny, but a gorgeous gown, sparkly jewels, a pretty purse and sexy shoes are a form of self expression: how youâ€™re feeling, what youâ€™re projecting and what youâ€™re hoping to get in return. Donâ€™t get me wrong, I know worldly things donâ€™t solve problems or buy self esteem, but showcasing the best of what you got for a special occasion can be a powerful thing and ultimately, itâ€™s about connection.

Whether youâ€™re dressing up for yourself, a lover or to relish in the holiday spirit, itâ€™s about opening ourselves up to what most of us long for â€” feeling special â€” if only for a moment, in our own little slice of this gi-normous, sometimes isolating world. When I look my best, I feel my best and I think thatâ€™s just part of being human. Maybe Iâ€™m vein, but Iâ€™d like to think Iâ€™m just being transparent.

When I was a young journalist, l used to go through severe bouts of depression. The long hours, working holidays, being away from my family, it really got to me. When Iâ€™d call home to be consoled, my mother would bark: â€œGet out of bed, wash your face, put some lipstick on and do something.â€ It was tough love, but it was also my momâ€™s way of telling me when you look half way decent, youâ€™re more likely to feel better about yourself and if you go out and connect with someone, make friends, meet a special someone or heck, go for a walk in the park, youâ€™ll probably be a more fulfilled person who sees the special qualities life has to offer.

Speaking of special, itâ€™s easy to feel that way at Dominque Boutique in Coral Gables. Itâ€™s been a secret fashion weapon of mine for years, especially around the holidays. When it comes to â€œParty Pizzazzâ€ thereâ€™s no other place in Miami that offers such beautiful, unique, one-of-a-kind dresses and thatâ€™s not all, itâ€™s literally one stop shopping.

You can build an entire outfit there with ease, they have jewelry, purses, gloves, evening shrugs, hats and more. Itâ€™s perfect for a girl on the go or a woman who has a lot demands on her life, but still wants something incredibly jaw-dropping. And, if youâ€™re lucky enough while youâ€™re there, youâ€™ll meet Dominque herself. Sheâ€™s an inspiring fashionista who oozes class and sophistication, so itâ€™s no surprise her store is a direct reflection of her fabulousness.

Whatever youâ€™re wearing this holiday season, I hope your â€œParty Pizzazzâ€ is accessorized with whatever your heart is longing for: love, peace, family, forgiveness, healing energy, health or just a moment of complete and utter happiness. I know this week Iâ€™ll be lucky enough to feel so many of those things with my closest friends and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s one of my Favorite Things. #KeyWestOrBust #HappyHolidays

item.title: Faux Fabulous
item.dc:creator: Steven Cejas
item.description: What: Showcasing the IT jacket of the season and why my first real fur coat broke my heart. Why: Iâ€™ll never forget my first fur...
item.content:encoded:
What:

Showcasing the IT jacket of the season and why my first real fur coat broke my heart.

Why:

Iâ€™ll never forget my first fur coat. It wasnâ€™t something I bought; I come from humble beginnings. Instead, itâ€™s something I inherited. Albeit, reluctantly.

My best friend in high school was a debutante from Texas and when she moved to New Mexico, we became fast friends. I loved everything about her; she had great style, oozed southern charm and was generous with her time and friendship. We got on famously. Actually, I wanted to be more like her. She was worldly and wise beyond her years.

A year before she became the new kid on the block, I had just moved to the Land of Enchantment, too. In the beginning, I think thatâ€™s what drew us together, but as time passed, it was more than that. Thereâ€™s nothing like young friendship. The bond is indescribable and helping one another get through those awkward, coming-of-age years was a pretty special thing, although I didnâ€™t know it at the time.

We would spend hours in her basement boudoir. Lol. Thatâ€™s what we used to call it. Her parents had converted it into a mini-apartment with a bedroom, bathroom, kitchenette and living room. She lived there in her own little paradise. She had beautiful things â€” gorgeous furry carpets, a gold trimmed vanity, a fluffy down comforter and a closet stuffed with designer clothes. She taught me about tennis, interesting books and how to match my perfume to my personality. I still miss her.

She died on a hot August day, a few weeks after my birthday and even though it was over twenty years ago, I still remember it like it was yesterday. I wish I could say I was devastated, but I sat in the front row at her funeral void of any kind of emotion. After everyone left, I lingered by her casket and wondered when the tears would come. They didnâ€™t.

I told her I was sorry we had drifted apart after high school and that I had always wondered why she stayed behind when everyone else had left for college. At the time, she seemed lost to me, but looking back on it now, maybe I was the one who was trying to find my place in the world while she had always known hers.

A few years later, she finally flew the coop. Not only did she find new purpose at a college in Las Cruces, she found love, too. She described him perfectly in her letters and when I talked to her on the phone she seemed genuinely happy. It made my heart sing and I couldnâ€™t wait to be reunited and talk about all the exciting things happening in both of our lives, but I would never see her again.

The knock at my dorm room came at an odd time and the person standing in the doorway wasnâ€™t someone I was expecting a visit from. He was a few years older than me and one of my brotherâ€™s best friends. He also happened to be from my hometown. We didnâ€™t run in the same circles. He was popular, good looking and most of the time ignored me when he saw me on campus, so his presence was disconcerting.

After an awkward “hello,” he grabbed my hand and led me to a chair and told me to sit down. Iâ€™m not exactly sure what happened after that, but I do remember the words falling out of his mouth in slow motion and only being able to comprehend some of them. Car, injuries, died. â€œIâ€™m so sorry,â€ he said and then, I heard nothing. I told him to leave. He didnâ€™t want to, but he did. My parents collected me the next day and we headed home so I could pay my respects.

After her funeral, her parents asked me to stop by the house. It was weird being there without her. It was sad, empty and grief was thick in the air. Her mother handed me a garment bag and said: â€œShe would have wanted you to have it.â€ I thanked her and left without opening it.

When I got home, I discovered her mother had gifted me my best friend’s most prized possession, her decadent fur coat. She used to dance around in it singing Madonna songs. She always promised to loan it to me, but I cheekily refused. I took the coat off its hanger, slipped it on, wrapped my arms tightly around myself and wept.

I never wore the coat again (until I put it on for the blog) but I did cry again – and again – and again. Over the years, I would buy more fur, but only re-purposed, as in vintage. As I grew into an educated woman, I stopped wearing it altogether for humane reasons. And while fashion today allows me to be â€œFaux Fabulous,â€ the trend still reminds me of my sweet friend from all those years ago.

I still have her coat. Iâ€™ve never been able to part ways with it. I hope some day Iâ€™ll be able to see her again and I hope every now and then her spirit brushes by me to say hello, even if I donâ€™t know it.

I realize now, the extra time she spent at home with her parents while her classmates, including myself, left for college was a true gift to her family. They got to spend more time with her before her life was cut short. All things have purpose, even if at the time they make no sense whatsoever. All these years later, that coat still breaks my heart, but itâ€™s all I have left of her, besides my fleeting memories.

I find peace knowing if she were still alive, she would have eventually turned into a â€œFaux Fabulousâ€ fashion lover like me and we would have danced in on our coats together; laughing, smiling and enjoying life, because it was one of our Favorite Things.

Where:
Lincoln Road Mall
744 Lincoln Road
Miami, Florida 33139
(on the corner of Lincoln Road and Meridian)

Be Social:
Local IG: @bonchic_miamibeach
#bcbgsouthbeach
Twitter: @BCBG
www.BCBG.com

â€œGrief is the price we pay for love.â€ â€” Queen Elizabeth II

James Woodley Photography
Faux Fur Red Coat by @BCBG #SouthBeach

Editor: Matthew “Just Faux You” Auerbach

item.title: Tea Time
item.dc:creator: Hans Morgenstern
item.description: What: Fabulous heels & hats at the 7th annual #HauteTea Luncheon & Hat Party benefiting the Diabetes Research Institute Foundation â€” the best hope for...
item.content:encoded:
What:
Fabulous heels & hats at the 7th annual #HauteTea Luncheon & Hat Party benefiting the Diabetes Research Institute Foundation â€” the best hope for a cure.

Why:
Iâ€™ll never forget my first time at #HauteTea; it was Miami fashion at its finest with amazing hats, gorgeous dresses and saucy shoes. Even more impressive…

The women attending the event who were community-minded, charity-driven and impossibly chic. I was so in awe, I could hardly concentrate on the task at hand: dishing details of the event for Deco Drive. After the story aired, I promised myself Iâ€™d go back, just to enjoy the beauty of it all.

Fast-forward four years and one fashion blog later, and #FavoriteThings was the perfect way to feature #HauteTea. Without pretense or my normal â€œgotta get the story and get outâ€ agenda, I walked around the event last Friday, during its pre-lunch cocktail hour, oohing and aahing over all the gorgeous headgear.

Instead of a fascinator for myself, though, I went with an elegant cocktail hat designed by Danielle Kukar, Founder of FeatherHeart Millinery in Fort Lauderdale. This yearâ€™s theme was #GardenParty, so I chose a sultry eggplant colored retro-inspired dress with a lively vine pattern by BCBG.

The one-shoulder design was a definite selling point for me because it easily mixes our summer & fall seasons, tropically speaking. While I love autumn textures, the heat and humidity is still alive and well in October; itâ€™s just part of living in South Florida. Another highlight of the outfit? Streamlined metallic stripes woven into the material, hinting at the holidays to come.

I hope you enjoy the pictures as much as I enjoyed an afternoon of hats & heels â€” because fashion with a charitable cause is always one of my Favorite Things.
